pullRequest.title: DHFPROD-6219:Remove '$ref' from empty entity instance
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description
Remove '$ref' from empty entity instance
Checklist:
- Note: do not change the below


Owner:


 JIRA_ID included in all the commit messages


 PR title is in the format JIRA_ID:Title


 Rebase the branch with upstream


 Squashed all commits into a single commit


 Code passes ESLint tests


 Added Tests


Reviewer:


 Reviewed Tests

nodes.bodyText: Since the if condition returns an empty sequence, this could be changed to a where clause with a not().
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -61,8 +62,34 @@ declare function data-hub-map-to-canonical(
     else map:map()=>map:with("template", $target-entity-name)
   let $results :=
     xdmp:xslt-invoke($mapping-uri||".xslt", $input, $user-params, $parms)
+  let $x := xdmp:log($results)
   return
     if ($format="xml")
     then inst:canonical-xml($results)
-    else inst:canonical-json($results)
+    else(
+      let $element := $results/element()
+      return
+      (: This change is necessitated by DHFPROD-6219. In case the entity doesn't have strucutred properties, it
+         returns empty json object. If it has structured properties, the empty structured properties are removed.
+         inst:canonical-json() method introduces the '$ref' .  :)
+      if (empty($element/*)) then
+        document{json:object()=>map:with(string(fn:node-name($element)), json:object())}
+      else
+        inst:canonical-json(xquery-lib:clean-xml($element))
+    )
+};
+
+
+declare function clean-xml($element as item()*) as document-node() {
+  document{
+    element {fn:node-name($element)} {
+      $element/namespace::node(),
+      $element/@*,
+      for $child in $element/element()
+      return

nodes.bodyText: Let's call this something more descriptive than "clean", which doesn't describe what it's doing. I think your comment indicates what the function name should be - perhaps "remove-empty-structured-properties"?

nodes.bodyText: These aren't really invalid, they're just missing, right? "invalid" implies to me that some sort of error should be thrown.

Do we need anything more than id and customer here? If not, let's remove these other mapping expressions, as they complicate the test. We want the bare minimum of everything to isolate the problem and verify it's fixed.
This doesn't look right - shouldn't "items" either be under "customer/properties" or at the same level as "customer"?
Same as above, use the simplest input doc possible to verify the problem is fixed.
Let's simplify the input doc to the bare minimum here - no transactionDate needed, and only need one item.

This is fine - no need to change - but a comment like this is best expressed as the assertion message - e.g.
test.assertEqual(null, instance.CustomerType, "Since none of the Customer properties are mapped, it should not exist in the entity instance");

There are two benefits to this:

If the test fails, we get a nice message as opposed to just that something isn't null
If the logic changes, or if the code is reorganized, the assertion message is almost guaranteed to stay in sync with the code, while the comment may not get updated or may not get moved
